content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The height of a diver above the water is given by \(h(t)=-5t^2+10t+3\), where \(t\) is time measured in seconds and \(h(t)\) is measured in meters. Select two statements that are true about the situation.

Correct! The diver begins 3 meters above the water. The function has 1 zero that makes sense in this situation.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.6.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: The diver begins 3 meters above the water. The function has 1 zero that makes sense in this situation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The height of a baseball, in feet, is modeled by the function \(h\) given by the equation \(h(t)=3+60t-16t^2\). The graph of the function is shown.

    1. About when does the baseball reach its maximum height? Round to the nearest second.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The baseball reaches its maximum height just before 2 seconds.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The baseball reaches its maximum height just before 2 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. About how high is the maximum height of the baseball? Round to the nearest ten.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The maximum height of the baseball is about 60 feet.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The maximum height of the baseball is about 60 feet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. When does the baseball hit the ground? Round to the nearest second.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The baseball hits the ground less than 4 seconds after the baseball was hit or thrown.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The baseball hits the ground less than 4 seconds after the baseball was hit or thrown. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Two rocks are launched straight up in the air. The height of Rock A is given by the function \(f\), where \(f(t)=4+30t-16t^2\). The height of Rock B is given by \(g\), where \(g(t)=5+20t-16t^2\). In both functions, \(t\) is time measured in seconds and height is measured in feet.

The following is a graph of the functions. Use the graph to answer the questions a–c.

    1. Which graph is the height of Rock A, \(f(t)=4+30t-16t^2\)?

Correct! The red graph represents Rock A.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.6.2 and 7.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The red graph represents Rock A. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which graph is the he height of Rock B, \(g(t)=5+20t-16t^2\)?

Correct! The green graph represents Rock B.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.6.2 and 7.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The green graph represents Rock B. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Determine which rock hits the ground first.

Correct! Rock B hits the ground first. The graph for Rock B (\(g(t)=5+20t-16t^2)\) crosses the \(x\)-axis at about 1.5, which means it hits the ground about 1.5 seconds after launch. The graph for Rock A (\(f(t)=4+30t-16t^2)\) crosses the \(x\)-axis at about 2, which means it hits the ground about 2 seconds after launch.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.6.2–7.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Rock B hits the ground first. The graph for Rock B \((g(t)=5+20t-16t^2)\) crosses the \(x\)-axis at about 1.5, which means it hits the ground about 1.5 seconds after launch. The graph for Rock A \((f(t)=4+30t-16t^2)\) crosses the \(x\)axis at about 2, which means it hits the ground about 2 seconds after launch. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Each expression represents an object’s distance from the ground, in meters, as a function of time, \(t\), in seconds.

Object A: \(-5t^2+25t+50\)

Object B: \(-5t^2+50t+25\)

  1. Which object was launched with the greater vertical speed?

Correct! Object B was launched with the greater vertical speed.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.6.2–7.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Object B was launched with the greater vertical speed. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which object was launched from the greater height?

Correct! Object A was launched from the greater height.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.6.2–7.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Object A was launched from the greater height. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
